Tiago Pedroso da Cruz de Andrade

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/6758293560844920
  • Última atualização do currículo em 26/08/2019

Possui graduação em Bacharelado em Ciências da Computação pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2009), mestrado em Ciência da Computação pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2013) e atualmente fazendo doutorado na Universidade Estadual de Campinas. Tem experiência na área de Ciência da Computação, com ênfase em Redes de Computadores, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: LTE, LTE-Advanced, Machine-to-Machine Communications, Device-to-Device Communications, Wireless Sensor Networks, Tecnologia Rádio-sobre-Fibra, Protocolos MAC. Conhecimento em simuladores para Redes de Computadores, tanto na parte de implementações de novas funcionalidades quanto na utilização. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2016 - 2019
FUTEBOL - Federated Union of Telecommunications Research Facilities for an EU-Brazil Open Laboratory
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Nelson Luis Saldanha da Fonseca em 01/08/2019.
Descrição: The overall objective of the FUTEBOL project is to develop and deploy research infrastructure, and an associated control framework for experimentation, in Europe and Brazil, that enables experimental research at the convergence point between optical and wireless networks..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (3) .

Integrantes: Tiago Pedroso da Cruz de Andrade - Integrante / Nelson Luis Saldanha da Fonseca - Coordenador / ASTUDILLO, CARLOS A. - Integrante / VILLAS, LEANDRO A. - Integrante / GAMA, EDUARDO S. - Integrante / MADEIRA, EDMUNDO R. M. - Integrante / Luiz Fernando Bittencourt - Integrante.
2015 - 2017
Techniques at the MAC Layer for Energy Saving in Smartphones
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Nelson Luis Saldanha da Fonseca em 01/08/2019.
Descrição: Current 4G/5G vision envisages higher data rates and multi-standard radio interfaces (LTE, Wi-Fi, DVB-H, Bluetooth, etc.) to provide users with a continuous seamless connection. Unfortunately, existing multi-standard devices exhibit high power requirements for maintaining two or more radio interfaces. Indeed, from the manufacturer?s perspective, the issue of power consumption is becoming a key concern since there is a continuously growing gap between the energy required by emerging mobile handsets and what can be actually achieved by: i) the evolution on battery technology; ii) the progress on scaling and circuit design; and iii) the development of novel thermal and cooling techniques. Therefore, one of the biggest challenges for the future wireless systems is the need to limit the energy consumption of battery-powered devices, with the aim to prolong their operational time and avoid active cooling. Without new approaches for energy saving, there is a significant threat that 4G mobile users will be searching for power outlets rather than for network access, thus being restricted to a single location and loosing the ability to roam freely. This project aims at developing variations of MAC protocols for potential incorporation in smartphones to save energy and therefore enhance users´ experience. This project focus on energy saving at the user equipment by means of novel Medium Access Control (MAC). The MAC layer is a key point for energy consumption control and energy saving through cross layering since it directly interfaces to the Physical layer and takes decisions affecting the usage and energy consumption of the radio transceiver. Duty cycling is a well-known technique for saving energy in wireless networks by allowing a node to turn off its radio transceiver for some periods of time. Unfortunately, this operation requires transitions between on and off states wherein the radio transceiver needs a certain switching time and generates extra power consumption, especially, the off-on or wakeup transition whose peak power is significantly high. Experimental measurements obtained from Motorola radio transceivers will allow the modeling of on/off, transitions of radio transceivers and the design of new energy-efficient variation of standard MAC protocols aware of the on/off radio transitions. In addition, the feasibility of combining duty cycling with network coding will be investigated for more aggressive energy savings. Moreover, the massive number of Machine-to-Machine (M2M) devices expected to share a cellular infrastructure with traditional Human-to-Human (H2H) users can overload the Radio Access Network of LTE/LTE-Advanced networks, leading to high access delay and low access probability. Devices can operate to decrease energy consumption in the random access procedure and in the uplink/downlink transmission while simultaneously guaranteeing QoS requirements to user's applications. The former will be achieve by exploring distributed random access mechanisms while the latter will explore cooperative relaying D2D communications, a new capability of user equipment devices recently introduced in the 3GPP standardization..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Tiago Pedroso da Cruz de Andrade - Integrante / Nelson Luis Saldanha da Fonseca - Coordenador / ASTUDILLO, CARLOS A. - Integrante / Raul Palacios-Trujillo - Integrante / Fernando Henrique Pereira - Integrante.
